docs.lead_paragraph: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In general I admire the common sense of the personal health reports of Jane Brody. However, in the report of March 17 there is a confusing misperception in the case of ''Bob.''
docs.snippet: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In general I admire the common sense of the personal health reports of Jane Brody. However, in the report of March 17 there is a confusing misperception in the case of ''Bob.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Treatment with interferon, a natural antivirus substance, reduced the severity of chicken pox infections in children undergoing drug treatment for cancer, according to a report in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. Chicken pox is a virus infection that is usually mild in children who are otherwise healthy. It can be deadly in patients who have leukemia or related forms of cancer and are being treated with anticancer drugs. Such drugs suppress the patient's normal defenses against infection.

headline.main: INTERFERON MAY EASE CHICKEN POX THREAT TO CANCER CHILDREN
